name: password reset flow
description: Initiate account recovery using the site's ‘Forgot password’ feature for the victim’s account.
why: A common recovery path abused to take over accounts.

name: intercept reset email
description: Open the reset email sent to the victim to complete the password change, by accessing their mailbox or a device already logged in.

name: weak/reused email password
description: Log into the victim’s email using previously leaked or reused credentials.

name: shared device still logged in
aliases: session still active on shared device
description: Use a shared or borrowed device where the victim is still logged in to their mailbox or portal.

name: Credential Stuffing
description: Try email/password pairs leaked from other sites to log in.

name: password spraying
description: Try a small set of common passwords across many users to avoid lockouts.

name: phishing for credentials
description: Trick the user into entering their password on a fake site or page controlled by the attacker.

name: lockout/rate-limit bypass
description: Slow attempts or rotate IPs and accounts to avoid lockout or rate limits.

name: Predictable Password Reset Token
description: The password-reset link uses a guessable token so attackers can take over accounts without email access.

name: No Rate Limiting on Reset
description: Reset flows allow unlimited attempts, enabling token/email brute-forcing and automation.

name: use stolen account’s saved card
description: Place orders using payment methods saved in a compromised account.

name: use leaked card details
description: Use a leaked card number with billing details to place fraudulent orders.

name: small test transactions
description: Run small test purchases to verify stolen card validity before larger orders.

name: stack discounts/referrals
description: Combine multiple discounts or referral credits in unintended ways to reduce order cost below acceptable limits.

name: false 'item not received' claim
description: Claim a legitimate order was not received to obtain a refund or replacement.

name: insecure direct object reference on orders
description: Access or modify another customer’s order by guessing or enumerating order identifiers.

name: join home Wi-Fi
description: Join the same local network as the camera (e.g., weak Wi-Fi password or guest access).

name: access local interface/RTSP
description: Access the camera’s local web interface or RTSP stream when on the same LAN.

name: default admin password
description: Log into the camera using factory default administrator credentials.

name: default or weak stream key
description: Use a default/weak streaming key to pull or push video streams without authorization.

name: predictable link pattern + enumeration
description: Predict the shape of document URLs (project names, dates, IDs) and enumerate to find valid links.

name: find exposed links in public repos/search
description: Locate document links inadvertently posted in public repositories, tickets, or search indexes.

name: use shared device/browser history
description: Recover document URLs from a shared computer’s history or recently-used items.

name: phishing for the link
description: Trick a user into sharing a supposedly private document link.

name: social engineering for sharing
description: Use pretexts to persuade someone with legitimate access to share the document link.

name: no or weak MFA
description: Accounts can be accessed without strong multi-factor; attackers succeed with only a password or a weak factor.

name: default credentials
description: Systems or services still use factory default usernames/passwords.

name: insecure direct object reference
description: Access or modify another user’s resource by guessing or changing identifiers without proper access control.

name: predictable identifiers
description: Resource identifiers follow simple sequences or patterns that are easy to enumerate.

name: session fixation
description: Attacker sets or predicts a victim’s session token and reuses it after the victim authenticates.

name: weak password policy
description: Password rules allow easily guessable secrets (short length, common words, no reuse checks).

name: SQL injection (basic)
description: User input is embedded into SQL queries without proper parameterization, allowing data access/modification.

name: reflected XSS
description: Untrusted input is reflected in responses without encoding, enabling script execution in the victim’s browser.

name: public cloud bucket exposure
description: A storage bucket/container is publicly readable or listable, exposing documents or data.

name: horizontal privilege escalation
description: Move sideways to another user’s data at the same privilege level (often via IDOR or shared links).

name: vertical privilege escalation
description: Gain higher privileges than intended (e.g., user → admin) through misconfigurations or logic flaws.

name: pretext phone/email request
description: Impersonate support or a colleague to request credentials, codes, or links.

name: abuse export/download feature
description: Use a legitimate export or download feature to exfiltrate data at scale.

name: insecure security questions
description: Account recovery via static questions with answers that are guessable or publicly known.

name: Credential Stuffing
description: Try email/password pairs leaked from other sites to log in. It works because many users reuse passwords across services. Success rates are low per attempt but scale with automation.
why: Very common real-world path to account takeover when passwords are reused.
mitigations: Have I Been Pwned-style breach checks at signup/login
Credential stuffing detection (IP/ASN velocity, device fingerprinting)
Adaptive rate limiting and risk-based challenges
refs: OWASP Automated Threats: OAT-008 Credential Stuffing

name: password spraying
description: Try a small list of very common passwords across many accounts to avoid per-user lockouts. Emphasizes breadth over depth.
why: Beats naive lockout rules because each account only gets a few attempts.
refs: OWASP Automated Threats: OAT-007 Password Spraying
CWE-307 Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts

name: phishing for credentials
description: Trick a user into entering their password (and sometimes a second factor) on a convincing fake page or consent screen.
why: Defeats even strong password policies and targets the human.

name: password reset flow
description: Trigger a reset for the victim account and complete it through recovery channels. Often the easiest takeover path if the attacker can reach the user’s email or reset token.
why: Recovery flows are as powerful as login but are less tested and often weaker.
mitigations: Strong, non-guessable reset tokens with short TTL

name: intercept reset email
aliases: open reset link in victim inbox
description: Access the victim’s mailbox (or a device already logged in) to click the reset link and finalize takeover.
why: Email is the master key for many accounts; inbox access bypasses strong login controls.

name: weak/reused email password
description: Log into the victim’s email using previously leaked or reused credentials, enabling reset-link capture and broader pivoting.
why: One successful email login often compromises many dependent services.

name: shared device still logged in
description: Use a shared or borrowed device where the victim’s session is still active to access accounts or recover links.
why: Bypasses authentication entirely via leftover sessions.
mitigations: Short idle/session lifetimes on untrusted devices

name: lockout/rate-limit bypass
description: Evade per-account or per-IP protections via distribution, rotation, or timing to keep guessing attempts under thresholds.
why: Turns weak rate limits into a speed bump instead of a control.
refs: CWE-307 Improper Restriction of Excessive Authentication Attempts

name: No Rate Limiting on Reset
description: Password reset and recovery endpoints allow unlimited or weakly-throttled attempts, enabling token/email brute forcing and automated abuse.
why: Reset flows must have protections equivalent to login.
mitigations: Global abuse detection on reset endpoints

name: Predictable Password Reset Token
description: Reset links or codes use insufficient randomness or length, making tokens guessable or enumerable.
why: Weak tokens allow takeover without inbox access.
mitigations: Use CSPRNG tokens ≥128 bits, base64/hex encoded
Bind tokens to account + request + short TTL
refs: CWE-330 Use of Insufficiently Random Values

name: no or weak MFA
description: Accounts can be accessed with only a password or a phishable second factor, leaving users exposed to credential compromise and social engineering.
why: Removes the safety net when passwords are compromised.
mitigations: Require phishing-resistant MFA for risky actions
Sunset SMS/email OTP for high-risk flows

name: shoulder surfing a password
description: Observe a victim entering their password to capture it without technical tools.
